newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Sri Lanka rupee gains on low demand for dollars.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka rupee gains on low demand for dollars.

text.p: The Sri Lanka rupee closed higher against the dollar because of the lack of commercial demand for the U.S. unit, dealers said.
The rupee closed at 57.13 to the dollar after opening at 57.28 and closing yesterday at 57.23.
"Early selling brought down the dollar, which stayed low due to a lack of import covering demand," said an American Express Bank dealer.
Dealers said the dollar would remain depressed locally despite its international strength, because of the lack of commercial and speculative demand and low call rates.
Overnight call money closed at 12.5 percent, with the market well offered, dealers said.
"Recent moves by the Central Bank to cut the reserve requirement and allow importers foreign exchange borrowings, could push money down further," said a Bank of Ceylon dealer.
Falling Treasury Bill yields are also an indication of the liquidity in the market, he said.
Dealers say the high level of market liquidity could result in the Central Bank further reducing its overnight repo rate, which now stands at 12 percent.
